awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Dylan Wilson is "Equivariant and chromatic homotopy theory." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Michael Hopkins.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI, along with collaborators, developed new computational and conceptual tools in the field of algebraic K-theory which were used to resolve a decades old conjecture (the Redshift Conjecture). Broadly speaking, this conjecture concerns the "computational complexity" of the task of classifying manifolds (i.e. high-dimensional shapes generalizing curves and surfaces). These techniques have since been incorporated into the state of the art for computations in algebraic K theory, and have provided a link with recent advances in arithmetic geometry (i.e. the work of Bhatt, Morrow, Scholze, Lurie, and others on prismatic cohomology). Prior to this work, the PI made several contributions to the field of equivariant homotopy theory, which is the study of the symmetries of shapes. This work has since inspired further research in the field, both theoretical and computational, including advances in an understanding of the higher structures present on invariants of shapes with symmetries.

Alongside this scholarly work, the PI was dedicated to broader service to the discipline. The PI co-organized several graduate student workshops built around problem-solving and inquiry-based learning; he mentored graduate students and served on an undergraduate advising committe; he participated in a committee dedicated to diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging; and he taught many courses whose syllabi were informed by inclusive pedagogy.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2023
Modified by: Dylan L Wilson
